citations.narrative:
On February 13, 2023 facility staff found two adult female kinkajous in poor condition (lying on the floor, not responsive,
gasping for breath). The licensee provided first aid and then took to animals to the Attending Veterinarian’s (AV) clinic
where they were hospitalized. The AV was contacted and reported that the two animals were severely dehydrated,
emaciated, hypothermic (low body temperature), hypoglycemic (low blood sugar) and not responsive upon presentation at
her clinic, with one animal markedly worse than the other. Despite aggressive medical interventions, one kinkajou
deteriorated and was euthanized the night of February 13th, 2023. The second animal remains hospitalized in intensive
care. The licensee brought two additional kinkajous (cage mates of the first two) in to the veterinary clinic on February
13th, 2023 at the AV’s request and these animals were observed by the AV to be extremely thirsty and were given fluids
by mouth before they were sent home.
According to the owner, the facility had been short staffed for approximately 1 week before February 13th. After this
incident, the licensee determined that the staff member in charge of caring for the kinkajous had not been adequately
feeding or watering them.
Staff members who not adequately trained and/or supervised may neglect or improperly care for animals. Animals who do
not have adequate food or water may suffer from thirst, hunger, weight loss, dehydration, or even death.
Correct by February 15, 2023 by ensuring that an adequate number of properly trained employees are utilized to maintain
professionally acceptable levels of animal care and husbandry. Animals must also be fed and watered adequately, and
handled carefully, in accordance with the Animal Welfare Act regulations.
This inspection was conducted with the facility manager and exit interview was conducted with the owner.
